comments.commentBody:
This is motorized hari-kiri.
Why not just do figure-eight racing then set themselves on fire?
It would be safer and more fun to watch.

I don't get what drives people to keep doing things like this after they've had such serious injuries, particularly before they become adults.  10 concussions?  Why do their parents not direct them to different pursuits?
Hurts to read this.
The folks running the X Games play up the spectacle at the expense of the sporting aspects of freestyle snowmobiling.
Yes, it's a sport called adrenaline addiction, kind of like being a jockey. I often wonder why people race horses as well.
I haven't been on a plane since before my twin boys were born, and they're 15 now...I figure I've missed the 15 worst years in the history of commercial aviation...
I don't think it follows that the future is bleak, especially when the people KNOW what is going on and are fighting for their future!
I don't think it follows that the future is bleak, especially when the people KNOW what is going on and are fighting for their future!
WE had nothing to do with the Murabek overthrow, and we have nothing to do with this. It is arrogant to think we pull strings to make things happen in the middle east.
This administration totally supported the overthrow of the Mubarak regime in the name of democracy.  As the old Chinese proverb has it, "Be careful what you wish for; you just might get it."
WE had nothing to do with the Murabek overthrow, and we have nothing to do with this. It is arrogant to think we pull strings to make things happen in the middle east.

One piece of the puzzle is living a lie for so many years it's embedded in their being. Like drug and alcohol addiction they need to discover and admit the lie before they can end the denial. As seen in high recidivism rates among the alcohol and drug addicted, seeing the light is not an easy process for Republican elitists. Perhaps taking advantage of the care of mental health professionals they deny to the poor would be a good place to begin.

Professor Krugman asks "Why is this happening? In particular, why is it happening now, just after an election in which the G.O.P. paid a price for its anti-populist stand?"  The answer may be as simple as they want to get what they can, while they can.  Corporate leaders in America aren't known for taking the long view about too many things, but instead tend to focus on short-term profit maximization.  While a different approach might help the long-term viability of the Republican party, it would also forgo potential short-term gains.

Another great leader said in 1937: "We had to struggle with the old enemies of peace--business and financial monopoly, speculation, reckless banking, class antagonism, sectionalism, war profiteering.

They had begun to consider the Government of the United States as a mere appendage to their own affairs. We know now that Government by organized money is just as dangerous as Government by organized mob.

Never before in all our history have these forces been so united against one candidate as they stand today. They are unanimous in their hate for me--and I welcome their hatred.

I should like to have it said of my first Administration that in it the forces of selfishness and of lust for power met their match. I should like to have it said of my second Administration that in it these forces met their master."

It's a great quotation, but Lincoln didn't say it. From: http://www.historyaccess.com/tenmisquotationa.html

"If you Google the first 10 or 12 words of this quotation along with "Lincoln" you will likely find an array of Internet sources that report the statement as authentic, including smug material from writers who chronicle their efforts to verify its authenticity. Lincoln never said it or wrote it. The quotation is a flat-out fraud, "the most notorious of the widely used and still current but false (Lincoln) quotations," writes quote maven George Seldes. The statement first emerged in the 1880s, Seldes notes, many years after Lincoln's death, during the Populist movement, when there was "Greenback agitation for 'paper' money as a panacea against 'Wall Street' monopoly." (See "Encyclopedia of the Great Quotations" by George Seldes [1960, p.22], "Lincoln, Labor, and Slavery" by Hermann Schluter [1913, p.170], and analyses by W.J. Ghent in Collier's Weekly [April 1, 1905], and Reinhard H. Luthin in Saturday Review [February 14, 1959]. See here for this Website's Lincoln pieces. See here for an article on this quote from Snopes.com, the excellent squelcher of rumors and falsehoods.)"

As a great leader once said; "The money powers prey upon the nation in times of peace and conspire against it in times of adversity. It is more despotic than a monarchy, more insolent than aristocracy, more selfish than bureaucracy. I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unerves me and causes me to tremble for the safety of my nation.
Corporations have been enthroned, and an era of corruption will follow, and the money power will engender to prolong it's reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until the wealth is aggregated in the hands of a few and the Republic is destroyed." Nov 21st, 1864

God help us, he was more right than he could have ever imagined.

The mechanism of action of both IUDs and emergency contraception (the morning-after pill) is actually to PREVENT FERTILIZATION, not implantation of a fertilized egg.  Therefore, these cannot be placed in the same category as abortion.  This is a commonly misunderstood mechanism, and one wishes that the NYTimes had taken the opportunity to correct this myth.

Tom,  you ask where are the spending cuts in state government; in education, that's where.  My state lost 3,500 educators due to cuts in state support for public schools.  The GOP plan is to divert as much tax-payer money as possible into for-profit charter schools, further eroding revenue available for the public schools.  After decimating the teacher ranks, they will wonder why achievement isn't better, thus justifying the diversion of funds to the charter schools.  Just watch it happen.

rewriter,  I would agree that education is one of the first things cut by the states to save money but it is a willfully short sighted and ultimately doomed to failure.  If a state or country is expected to grow and prosper longer than the next election cycle, an educated workforce is needed.  Much of the data shows that income inequality grows as the educational level declines so it plays right into the hands of those who would want a plutocracy.  The unintended consequence of such policy is an uneducated electorate that can be swayed by emotion rather than logic and rhetoric rather than facts.

What I find most conflicting is Republicans claiming they favor makers.  In order to do this, they claim they want to cut taxes and yet many proposals in state legislatures are talking about adding sales taxes (which are regressive) and fees in order to cut income taxes.  In the simple analysis, who among the makers benefits from these plans?  High income makers get a big tax break because of their income and pay relatively a small portion of their income in sales taxes while low income makers get a small income tax break but pay a much higher proportion of their income in sales taxes so once again, the average working American at the low end of the income brackets ends up increasing proportion of taxes coming from his or her paycheck simply because they spend almost all of it on milk, gas, groceries and rent while the upper income makers see a relatively large increase in their tax home pay.  Second, where are the spending cuts in state government (other than the ever smaller social safety net)?  I haven't seen any spending cuts.  Lastly, to paraphrase a famous person.  The trouble with our Conservative friends is not that they're ignorant; it's just that they know so much that isn't so.
Excellent comment.  Thank you.

Hi David Lewis,

I don't like your first paragraph, too many "if's".

But take heart, I have found this to cheer you:

"These are the times that try men's souls; the summer soldier and the sunshine patriot will, in this crisis, shrink from the service of his country; but he that stands for it now, deserves the love and thanks of man and woman. Tyranny, like hell, is not easily conquered; yet we have this consolation with us, that the harder the conflict, the more glorious the triumph." -- Thomas Paine

Plutocracy is on its way out, 1% can never stand for too long as masters of 99% -- or even 47%. It is just a matter of time.

Cheers, JBS
http://johnbrianshannon.com

All this self-congratulation by the left (or what's left of it) is really really dangerous and misguided. A few fewer Romney gaffes -- a slightly better campaign strategy -- a candidate with a modicum of a clue -- another couple gaffes by Obama -- any one of a number of things and the election would have gone the other way and we'd all be singing a very different and sadder tune.,

Nope, the plutocratic right is still alive, well and kicking. The latest round of proposals to subject presidential elections to congressional-district gerrymandering is one example of how dangerous they are. And the gerrymandered House and right-wing Supreme Court still have the all the monkey wrenches they need to stop the government from functioning, even though they've now lost the debt limit tool, which Obama never should have let them have in the first place.

Sorry, but there's a long way to go before we achieve progressive nirvana -- I'm not sure the recent election can even be considered the step before the step before the beginning of the end of plutocratic rule of America. I'm not even sure it is possible without... oh shoot... who wants to talk about that...

If your knees are "killing" you, I suspect trigger points in the quads and lateral thigh (tensor fascia latae). Sit down, take a rolling pin, and run it down your thigh while pressing into the muscle with fairly strong pressure. Do you feel painful "speed bumps" under your rolling pin? Run the rolling pin down the lateral thigh to check there too. 99% of the time, if a client has painful knees, I find these painful lumpy bumps (trigger points) in the quads, TFL and IT Band. Simple solution though: get a therapeutic massage (NOT a fluff-and-buff) or use bodyrolling techniques to work them out. Examples here:
Quads: http://youtu.be/k2-3whT5-6k?t=42s
TFL: http://youtu.be/WFLzyLv8R1w
IT Band: http://youtu.be/wr2mQmF5R-Y

In my experience, these triggers usually pop up due to taking on a new exercise or a new kind of movement at an unsustainable intensity, where the knee extensors & stabilizers can't keep up. So, work out the triggers, THEN add knee strengthening exercises but at a slow-and-steady level of intensity. Don't overdo it, Weekend Warrior, or those triggers will be back.

The notion that squatting with added weight is an "artificial exercise" makes no sense and it only adds to the false and inaccurate belief held by many that weight training is somehow an inorganic and risky activity.

Humans have been lifting weights, in one form or another, and squatting for as long as we have existed. Its a basic functional movement and when done with added resistance it does a lot more than just strengthen a "specific muscle group". Properly performed squats will decrease your risk of injury by strengthening the quadricep, hamstring, gluteal and spinal erector muscle groups, to name a few.

In order to get stronger you have to strength train and it becomes more important as we age. The whole concept of progressive resistance exercise ie; weight-training, is based on the ancient Greek legend of Milo of Crotona, who is said to have carried a calf on his shoulders every day until it became a full grown bull. Lifting weights is a natural and necessary activity as long you want to live a physically "functional" and independent life.

Mike:

I wish you would provide me of some examples where humans would naturally prefer to lift weight by something similar to the squat.

I have been around amateur and professional exercise experts and have talked with a lot of people who damaged their spine or knees with squatting. Of course you can always say they weren't doing the exercise correctly but that's kinda my point.

BTW how did Milo get the calf up to his shoulders? And I really think the story is a bit of an exaggeration.

The first rule in any exercise program, and this can't be overstated, is your first and absolute priority is to not injure yourself.

You have to look at what your exercise goals are, what type of activities you want to participate in, and what biomechanic limitations you have. Absolutely don't do anything that involves any pain or feels abnormal.

Functional exercises/activities are much more appropriate and beneficial for aging individuals than some artifical activity to strength a specfic muscle group.

Squatting is an activity which humans and other mammals use primarily for defecation. it seems to me to have fairly limited use to most mammals. It is probably good to mimic this activity somewhat, since in western society we use toilets and don't have to squat very much. But to artifically strengthen these muscles may not be advantageous for the population at large.

Squats, particularly with added weight seem to me to be a fairly artificial exercise, what situation in nature would a primate squat or than for defecation? I can't think of any, this is rarely how you would lift weight.

Better for most people to orient their exercise programs to funtional activities which they enjoy.
Thanks! Good tips! Much appreciated.
I don't know how this article did not mention what I have always been told is the cardinal rule of squats - keep your weight in your heels.

Anybody in their 60's who is seriously considering doing squats to improve their knee function should first have their head examined. Repetitive knee squats if done continously over time  is a recipe for trouble.. Instead try positions which gently flex the joint like sitting in a semi-lotus postition or, while lying on your back, bringing each knee slowly to the chest without forcing.

When my knees started to twinge a few years ago, I dug out my old ballet excercises - but not the pink satin shoes. Five minutes of plies every day has made a tremendous  difference to my knees and to the muscularity of my legs and lower body.  Who knew?

Try Anatabloc.  I am 60 years old and have been doing tae kwon do for the last 3 and 1/2 years.  My knees have bothered me since I was in my late thirties.  Mostly I took advil and used ice on them.  Since starting Anatabloc about 4 months ago, I have been moving much better and not taken advil for relief since.  Google it and then give it a try.  Big difference in my quality of life!
What exactly is meant by "strange, clicking noise"?  Is there a clicking noise in the knee that isn't strange?  Does "strange" imply concomitant pain?
The suggestion came from a great physical therapist!

Actually it's not a very good exercise at all.  Typically those people who are told to do it have tight ankles/feet.  If the lower leg is tight it puts more stress to the knee.  It's better to work on flexibility/ROM on the foot/ankle complex.  It's believed this wall squat will strengthen the "quads".  The quads are designed to work with all of the leg muscles not just on their own.

I agree with the suggestion of using the exercise ball between the back and the wall. This is the only way you can be sure that you are doing squats in a way that doesn't harm your knees. And whatever you do, skip the lunges. If anything, take the stairs.
